Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

what can a for loop do that a while loop cant?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89842566
a for loop automatically performs an action at the beginning & during each cycle as well as having an exit condition. This can more cleanly encapsulate variables which are only important to the loop
for (beginning, condition, action) {
    ...code...
}

instead of 
begnning
while (condition) {
    action
    ...code...
}


all of it is just syntactical sugar over GOTO

No /fwt/ Edition

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.
(Does not work on VL editions that need KMS, avoid VL/KMS)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i

There are no compatibility differences between versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try LibreOffice and set it to save as Office file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:

>re-using one time pads
Man, are people really that dumb? One time pads aren't some magical secure encryption algorithm, they're just a form of brute force encryption through randomized data deltas. threads.com:
DEEP DIVE Mouse Controller Question:
How does my faster mouse movement get translated into faster cursor acceleration on my screen?

I'm trying to build my own mouse, and the guides and code I've read through so far seem to just poll for if the mouse has moved. Which means that translation happens directly on the mouse IC, and it's just pulling the data that the mouse spits out after that calculation has been done. I want to know what's happening on the mouse IC that is figuring out the physical mouse is moving more quickly.

Because another driver I read that was for the mouse IC itself was just polling for if a specific button was pressed. (It was a project to use buttons for up, down, left, and right.) And the cursor would just moved any particular direction based on how long that button was held down. Which means there shouldn't be any intelligent acceleration possible. It's time dependent and could only possibly have acceleration based on the polling rate of whatever is looking for a signal from that button press. AKA the longer the button is held down, the acceleration is assumed to continue going based on some pre-set rate. <(Where and how is that rate determined?)

Now, assuming that button project didn't have any acceleration based on button press time, which I'm not sure it does...

How the hell is any mouse determining an acceleration is happening, how does that information get sent to/interpreted by the mouse IC, how does that mouse IC then send that data to the mouse driver?

I was really hoping it was just ultimately that higher voltage differentials get interpreted as higher acceleration, at some point in the pipeline. Because the mouse I want to build can easily generate voltage differentials, that increase based on the acceleration, for the x-y axis.

I want to just nestle my code seamlessly into the existing mouse controller hierarchy, with doing as little self-work as possible.

last_replies.com:
>>89839443
>doing as little self-work as possible

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89840660

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89840192
What you get from a USB mouse is effectively a delta X and a delta Y. If you keep track of a current cursor position and add these deltas to it, times a scale factor you get from your mouse speed setting, you should have roughly linear mouse movement with no acceleration.
To add acceleration, you want to multiply the deltas by a second scale factor that is larger when delta values are larger.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89840192
... I'm not sure what signals are present inside an optical mouse, but there's a chip with an image sensor that compares sequences of images to find motion. Idk how that communicates with the rest of the stuff in the mouse though. For ball mice, you have optical encoder wheels. These have little holes around the edge and two infrared LED/sensor pairs shining through the holes. They're offset from each other such that sensors 1 and 2 will give pulses like 12...12...12 as the wheel spins one direction, and 21...21...21 when it spins the other way. The IC in the mouse counts these pulses to get the delta values it sends to the computer.
Acceleration calculations are performed in software on the computer. Mice themselves are linear.
